item.title: The Fallacy of needing a technical manager
item.description: One of the things I’ve come across most in my career in technology (and one that still persists) is the belief that as an engineer, your manager (or coach) needs to be fairly technical as well.

item.title: Pen and Paper
item.description: A couple of years ago I went from working in an office to working remote mostly from home.

item.title: Factors of Confidence
item.description: I’ve been having a lot of discussions about delivery of software lately and especially about the deployment part of it.

item.title: Capacity planning for Etsy’s web and API clusters
item.description: I wrote about how we do capacity planning for our web and API clusters on Etsy’s engineering blog.

item.title: Learning to have an engineering vision
item.description: Saying that the last 18 months or so were stressful and full of changes would be a colossal understatement.

item.title: Make and Go for Fun and Profit
item.description: I’ve been somewhat interested in Go for quite a while now.

item.title: Optimize for Mutability and the Present
item.description: I recently read John Vincent’s very interesting and honest blog post about being paralyzed because of seeing all the flaws in systems.

item.title: Bash Unit Testing from First Principles
item.description: In the last couple of months I’ve done a foray into unit testing the shell scripts I write.

item.title: I don't like Breaking Things
item.description: I don’t like breaking things. I never have. I hate it.

item.title: Take Pride in Your Code
item.description: If you’re working as a software engineer, you have very likely already heard about ‘egoless programming’.

item.title: My 2015 Reading List
item.description: This year has been really good for reading for me. Starting off from last year’s list and the 5-ish books I read in 2014, I made it to 16 this year.

item.title: Chef Driven Graphite Dashboards
item.description: Some years ago I wrote about how to use Heroku and a set of hosted solutions for getting started with monitoring for your personal infrastructure.

item.title: Timeouts And Reflections
item.description: I love coffee. I really do. And yet I haven’t had any for 4 days now.

item.title: How I prepare for and give conference talks
item.description: I thoroughly enjoy reading about how other people do their work, tackle problems, find productivity, and prepare for talks.

item.title: My Writing Workflow
item.description: I love writing. A lot. It’s one of the things that helps me the most with structuring thoughts and opinions I have.

item.title: Practical Postmortems at Etsy
item.description: I wrote an article on InfoQ about the way we conduct Blameless Postmortems at Etsy.

item.title: Adventures in Frontend Performance
item.description: In my daily job I am far removed from being a frontend engineer.

item.title: Open Source Spring Cleaning
item.description: I wrote about our plans to clean up our open source repositories and be good maintainers on Etsy’s engineering blog.

item.title: Accounting: The Unix Way
item.description: I’m a big fan of simple tools and building blocks. A function of writing code every day for the last 10 years has been that I feel really comfortable with plain text files, vim and git.

item.title: There's No Such Thing as No Project Management
item.description: Project management. Every engineer seems to loathe the term and also what it describes.

item.title: First month with the Spark Notebook
item.description: When the Spark Notebook got announced on Kickstarter I was first a bit hesitant as I have struggled before balancing digital and paper notes.

item.title: Deployment is Unix
item.description: Over the last 3 years I’ve worked a lot on Etsy’s deployment system (we’ve recently brought the Open Source version back into sync with our internal changes and are running on the public version now as well).

item.title: You Shouldn't Have To Ask For Forgiveness
item.description: A couple of days ago I was part of a private email thread about the popular Grace Hopper quote “It’s easier to ask forgiveness than it is to get permission.

item.title: You're building a Plant
item.description: As an infrastructure engineer you’re building a plant. Not literally of course but it’s also not too far off.

item.title: The Road to Success is paved with Small Improvements
Learning to be On-Call
item.description: I stumbled upon this great blog post about on-call the other day.

item.title: 2014 Reading List
item.description: This year I tried again to keep up the flow of reading books.

item.title: 3 Simple Things that improved my Work-Life Balance
item.description: These days productivity and work life balance are two parts of the holy grail of modern life for a lot of people.

item.title: Code Reviews Considered Awesome
item.description: I think by now it is pretty much accepted that collaboration and working together is a lot better than assigning blame and yelling at each other.

item.title: My Rules for E-Mail Happiness
item.description: Over the last couple of days and maybe weeks a lot of my friends, coworkers and most of all people I follow on twitter have been overly excited about the beta availability of an e-mail client.

item.title: Bye Bye Fitbit
item.description: About a year ago I decided that I had to do something about my fitness.

item.title: Mirror GitHub repositories in pure shell
item.description: As I have written before I have slowly started to move my data out of cloud services where applicable.

item.title: Human Error and Getting off the Hook
item.description: I’ve been interested in the field of human error and system safety for a while now.

item.title: Productive VIM with templates
item.description: I basically exist inside of vim all day. I write code in there, I write emails in VIM via mutt, I take notes with it and I write all my blog posts in VIM.

item.title: Shared layout for project pages in Jekyll
item.description: I use Jekyll a lot, especially for my website. And I quite like it a lot.

item.title: Computer Positivity
item.description: Let’s face it, we’ve all been there, your database just decided to split brains, Linux just killed Apache on your web servers because another process was using a bit more memory, your app is broken because the type system of the language you wrote it in has interesting assumptions about what object you just passed to a function and your laptop keeps disconnecting from the Wi-Fi.

item.title: How OmniFocus controls my life
item.description: At this point it’s pretty fair to say that OmniFocus rules my life.

item.title: A Whirlwind Tour of the Etsy Monitoring Stack
My 5 years of GitHub
item.description: In early 2009 I was very much not the typical programmer.

item.title: Backups with rsync and zfs
item.description: As I mentioned before I’m running my own backup on a server that is running in my apartment.

item.title: Git - Put the stupid back in stupid content tracker
item.description: Git describes itself as a stupid content tracker. While this was surely meant as a clever pun and an understatement, there is some truth to it.

item.title: Context specific dotfiles
item.description: I have a collection of various dotfiles which I use to configure the most important tools I use everyday.

item.title: Creating Encrypted Home Directories in FreeBSD
item.description: I run FreeBSD with ZFS on all my servers and I generally want to have my home directories encrypted.

item.title: My Tmux Setup
item.description: I’ve been using tmux as my main terminal multiplexer for about 3 years now and have refined my configuration over time to fit my daily workflow.

item.title: Uncloud your Life
item.description: There has been a lot of talk lately about privacy in the cloud and owning your own data.

item.title: Feature Flagging your Infrastructure for Fun and Profit
Infrastructure upgrades with Chef
item.description: I wrote about how we roll out infrastructure upgrades with Chef on Etsy’s engineering blog.

item.title: IRC notifications with logstash
item.description: I have spent some time in the last weeks to learn more about logstash and used the kind of bad state of my IRC notifications as the fun side project to get into it.

item.title: Getting started with monitoring on the cheap and easy
item.description: This post started out as a writeup of tools and services I use to monitor my small (currently 3) set of personal servers.

item.title: Deploying Sensu monitoring on Heroku
item.description: Sensu - trying to unsuck monitoring Some months ago I wanted to set up monitoring for a handful of servers I use for personal stuff.

item.title: Setting up workstations with Chef (Newbie Edition)
item.description: I have wanted to reinstall and cleanly set up my iMac at home for some time now.

item.title: gtd-couch - GTD as a couchapp
item.description: Why another GTD app? Over the last years I have tried a lot of task management applications.

item.title: Testing couchapps with cucumber
item.description: Couchapps overview [Couchapps][2] are a great way to build web apps hosted directly on a CouchDB.

item.title: Introducing Ramrod Command Center
item.description: I have [finally][2] registered my Master’s thesis. This means in 6 month my university life is over and the hard and cruel reality begins.

item.title: Chipping in on Textmate to Vim switching
item.description: There was some buzz lately about people considering [Vim][2] as their main editor and especially going from [Textmate][3] to Vim.

item.title: Notifo
item.description: [Notifo.com][notifo] is a web service which enables you to send push notifications to your mobile device (at the moment there is only support for the iPhone).

item.title: Thunk.us Python wrapper
item.description: Lately I have become more and more interested in APIs (especially on the web).

item.title: Where's ma ketchup?
item.description: At our office mondays are special. This is the one day Bobby drives his good old trailer to the parking lot of the supermarket next to the office and sells chicken and fries.

item.title: instapaperlib
item.description: For some time now instapaper.com is one of the web services I use most.

item.title: plustache
item.description: Some time ago I discovered [@defunkt’s][@defunkt] logic less ruby templating system [mustache][mustache].

item.title: Almost Endless Screen Real Estate
item.description: Ye olde setup Some months ago I realized that my Mac mini, used as a media server in my livingroom, has been getting a bit long in the tooth.

item.title: Google Reader to Instapaper bridge
item.description: The dilemma For some years now I am using Google Reader as my reader of choice for news feeds.

item.title: About
item.description: Hi! I’m Daniel! I’m an infrastructure engineer at GitHub. When I’m not working on infrastructure, I’m usually having coffee, draw, play basketball or watch TV shows.

item.description: This is an interview I did for “How I vim” and was originally published here.

item.description: In early 2011 I had finished university (again) and decided that I didn’t want to drink bad coffee anymore.

item.description: At this point it’s pretty fair to say that OmniFocus rules my life.
